title: Projects
text: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) is an inflammatory bowel disease that is characterized by chronic inflammation of thelarge intestine, causing ulcerations and debilitating symptoms. Studies have found that UC is characterizedby dysregulated cellular and microbial communities. These mechanisms have been studied separatelythrough single-cell RNA-sequencing (scRNAseq) and investigation of multi-omics in the gut. However, therehas been limited exploration of how microbial and metabolic states directly relate to specific cell-typeexpression in UC. To close this gap, we developed a multi-omic approach, integrating scRNAseq and paired metabolomic and bulk human transcriptome data to score individual cells based on metabolite signatures from bulk data. I am currently working through this project for my dissertation, preprint and GitHub repository coming soon.

title: Projects
section: Mouse-to-human modeling of microglia single-nuclei transcriptomics identifies immune signaling pathways and potential therapeutic candidates associated with Alzheimer’s disease
text:
Mouse-to-human modeling of microglia single-nuclei transcriptomics identifies immune signaling pathways and potential therapeutic candidates associated with Alzheimer’s disease

Preprint | Code
Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease characterized by memory loss and behavior change. Studies have found that dysregulation of microglial cells is pivotal to AD pathology. These mechanisms have been studied in mouse models to uncover potential therapeutic biomarkers. Despite these findings, there are limitations to the translatable biological information from mice to humans due to differences in physiology, timeline of disease, and the heterogeneity of humans. To address the inter-species discrepancies, we developed a novel implementation of the Translatable Components Regression (TransComp-R) framework, which integrated microglia single-nuclei mouse and human transcriptomics data to identify biological pathways in mice predictive of human AD. We compared model variations with sparse and traditional principal component analysis. We found that both dimensionality reduction techniques encoded similar AD disease biology on mouse principal components with limited differences in technical performance. Several mouse sparse principal components explained high amounts of variance in humans and significantly differentiated human AD from control microglial cells. Additionally, we identified FDA-approved medications that induced gene expression profiles correlated with projections of healthy human microglia on mouse principal components. Such medications included cabergoline, selumetinib, and palbociclib. This computational framework may support uncovering cross-species disease insights and candidate pharmacological solutions from single-cell datasets. I’ve linked the preprint and GitHub repository for this project.

Hi, my name is Alex Bergendorf!
I am a second-year Systems Biology and Bioinformatics PhD student at Case Western Reserve University. I have a strong background in biomedical data science as well as inflammatory and immune-implicated diseases through my academic and professional experiences.
I currently perform research on uncovering host-microbe interactions in the gut and female reproductive tract. My research is focused on developing and applying novel deep learning and statistical methods to uncover novel microbiome-based treatments for inflammatory conditions.
My professional goal is to continue applying and developing cutting-edge methods to uncover insights to improve the wellbeing of those suffering with disease.
Please feel free to contact me or (630) 776-6367 if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects.
